16. It is the well-known practice of Tintoretto
to compose thus, with groups or small knots/clusters,
and Michelangelo’s Last Judgment is also
arranged with clusters; though some stain his honor,
not because of these small groupings
but because, for the sake of figures,
he erred in the interest of composition,
for there is no entrance for the eyes.

17. Not revealing, as some would do,
a vista opening to the sky,
and in front something large, as would be desired:
but how should this not be taken for the best,
seeing this work flooded full of art
from the learned hand of Buonarrotti,
so many different positions of styles
of nudes, which were his concern.
left-middleMichelangelo, in his Last Judgement, paid more attention to his Figures than to his composition.

18. Also one can easily understand
that the law of composition is for the people,
but that it is not for the people to preserve the law;
for laws serve the people for good,
so that no shame may befall them,
What else had the laws to command?
So we may excuse such Masters
who pay more attention to figures than to composition.
left-middleLaws serve people for the best.

19. It is very commendable to seek
attractiveness in figures, and never to stray from this,
but there is a greater abundance
of excellence when the composition
is similar to this as well;
and just as the sound of musicians
makes harmony from singing and playing,
so here, too, do many different figures.

20. Nature’s beauty lies in variety.
One sees this as the earth, blooming with
almost a thousand colors, displays itself for praise,
vying with the starry throne of heaven,
as appealing delight can be perceived
in many other things: for without a care,
people enjoy themselves at an assortment
Of food and drink at a table.
